titleproper.value: Guide to the Edna Huntington papers and photographs <num>ARC.044</num>

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-11-07T20:35:46</date>

extent.value: in three manuscript boxes, one phase box, and one oversize folder

abstract.value: The Edna Huntington papers and photographs, dated 1905 to 1965, are organized into three series: <emph render="bold">Brooklyn Research</emph>, <emph render="bold">Personal Papers</emph>, and <emph render="bold">Photographs</emph>. While <emph render="bold">Brooklyn Research</emph> gives a focused view of Huntington's work as a librarian, <emph render="bold">Personal Papers</emph> provides a broader perspective on her career and its impact, as well as her education, her hobbies, and travels during her career. <emph render="bold">Photographs</emph> complements travel journals in the <emph render="bold">Personal Papers</emph> series with black-and-white prints and negatives of Huntington's vacations with her travel companion, Stella Kline.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Edna Huntington papers and photographs, ARC.044, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

Edna Huntington (1895-1965) attended PS 131 in Brooklyn and later completed Columbia University's Home Study courses in Librarianship. She began working for the Long Island Historical Society (now Brooklyn Historical Society) in 1926 and served as Head Librarian from 1936 to 1960. In addition to her work as a librarian, Huntington was an avid traveler. During the 1920s and 1930s, she planned a number of hiking and camping trips throughout the northeast United States and documented her excursions with photographs and detailed travel journals.

She photographed streets, buildings, and people in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Downtown Brooklyn, Brooklyn Heights, DUMBO, Fort Greene, Boerum Hill, Carroll Gardens Cobble Hill, Brownsville, Midwood, Bay Ridge, Gowanus, Flatbush, Fort Hamilton, Windsor Terrace, Brighton Beach, Prospect Park, Prospect Heights, Sheepshead Bay, Gravesend, Bensonhurst, Flatlands, East Flatbush, Borough Park, Coney Island, Bath Beach, Dyker Heights, Cypress Hills, New Lots, Canarsie, New Lots, Bedford Stuyvesant, Mill Basin, Marine Park, Ridgewood, Park Slope, East New York, Clinton Hill, Williamsburg, Bushwick, and Manhattan Beach.

dsc.value:
Series 1: Brooklyn Research19230.5 Linear Feetin two manuscript boxes.1926-1960Scope and Contents

This series consists of research notes made by Huntington on various topics related to Brooklyn and Long Island history, including authors, mills, cemeteries, historic markers, and monuments. Also included is a copy of "Historical Markers and Monuments in Brooklyn" with marginal notes by Huntington.

Series 2: Personal Papers19241.95 Linear Feetin two manuscript boxes and one oversize folder1887-1965Scope and Contents

Personal Papers includes Huntington's early school records and Manual Training High School diploma; correspondence relating to her library education at Columbia University and obtaining her position as librarian at the Long Island Historical Society (LIHS); travel journals, 1920-1940; a ration book; certificates; newspaper clippings; a scrapbook compiled by LIHS staff as a retirement gift; genealogical papers; bookplates; and the printing block for her personal bookplate.

Series 3: PhotographsV1997.01219250.9 Linear Feetin one manuscript box and one phase box.1917-1941Scope and Contents

Photographs contains negatives, black-and-white prints, and scrapbooks (titled "Travelogues") of Huntington's travels and outdoor activities, including hiking, camping, and canoeing. This series documents her almost yearly vacations from 1917 to 1941. Images show natural landscapes, camp grounds, and informal shots of Huntington and her travel companion, Stella Kline. Four scrapbooks written by Huntington and Kline combine dozens of photographs with a detailed narrative of each trip. Their destinations included the New England states, Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, Canada, the Smoky Mountain region, and Bermuda.
